case_name: Rabia Bai v. Custodian-General of Evacuee Property

facts.text: This is an appeal by special leave directed against the order passed by the Custodian-General of Evacuee Property, New Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: Gajendragadkar, J. This appeal by special leave is directed against the order passed by the respondent, the Custodian-General of Evacuee Property, New Delhi,

facts.text: The Custodian-General confirmed the orders of subordinate authorities rejecting the appellant's application for confirmation of the sale transaction under s. 40(4)(a) of the Administration of Evacuee Property Act, XXXI of 1950.

anchor.surface_text: in a revision petition confirming the orders of the subordinate authorities whereby the application made by the appellant for confirmation of the sale transaction in question has been rejected under s. 40(4)(a) of the

facts.text: Appellant Rabia Bai is a citizen of India residing at Grange, Yercaud, in the Salem District.

anchor.surface_text: Administration of Evacuee Property Act, XXXI of 1950. The appellant, Rabia Bai, who is a citizen of India having her residence at Grange, Yercaud, in the Salem District,

facts.text: Rabia Bai came to know in 1949 that premises No. 20, Godown Street, G.T., Madras, was for sale.

anchor.surface_text: came to know in 1949 that premises No. 20, Godown Street, G.T., Madras, was for sale. Since the appellant desired to acquire some immoveable property she arranged

facts.text: Rabia Bai arranged for the purchase of the premises through her husband.

anchor.surface_text: for the purchase of the said premises through her husband. The said premises belonged to one Mohamad Gani Jan Mohamad who had left for Pakistan in 1947 and had

facts.text: Premises belonged to Mohamad Gani Jan Mohamad who left for Pakistan in 1947 and settled there.

anchor.surface_text: settled there. The said Mohamad Gani Jan Mohamad had executed a power of attorney in favour of his nephew, Ahmed Abdul Gani. The said Gani came to Madras in April,

facts.text: Mohamad Gani Jan Mohamad executed a power of attorney in favour of his nephew Ahmed Abdul Gani.

anchor.surface_text: 1949, and arranged for the sale, and as a result of negotiations between him and the appellants husband the latter entered into a written agreement with the former

anchor.surface_text: on April 29, 1949, to purchase the said property for Rs. 2,40,000/-. A substantial part of the consideration to the extent of Rs. 1,50,000/- was paid immediately

facts.text: Written agreement entered on April 29, 1949 to purchase property for Rs. 2,40,000/- between appellant's husband and Ahmed Abdul Gani.

anchor.surface_text: in the form of cash and bank drafts. Thereafter the sale deed was duly engrossed and sent to Karachi for execution by the vendor. After it was received back duly

facts.text: Sale deed engrossed and sent to Karachi for execution by vendor, received back and stamped on June 27, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: before the said document could be registered, and soon after the said certificate was obtained the document was presented for registration and was duly registered

facts.text: Sale deed registered on August 11, 1949 after obtaining income-tax clearance certificate.

anchor.surface_text: on August 11, 1949. The balance of the consideration of Rs. 30,000/- was paid before the registering officer to Mr. M. H. Ganni who also held a power of attorney

facts.text: Balance consideration of Rs. 30,000/- paid before registering officer to Mr. M. H. Ganni who held power of attorney from vendor.

anchor.surface_text: from the vendor. That is how the appellant obtained title to the property in suit. As we will point out the appellant applied for confirmation of this sale deed

facts.text: Appellant applied for confirmation of the sale transaction on December 19, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: The application made by the appellant for confirmation of her purchase has been dealt with under the relevant provisions of the Act, and we would therefore refer

facts.text: Application resisted by tenants.

anchor.surface_text: to the said provisions hereafter. On December 19, 1949, the appellant applied for confirmation of the sale transaction in her favour. This application was resisted

facts.text: Assistant Custodian declared vendor's property evacuee property on January 11, 1951 under s. 7(1).

anchor.surface_text: It appears that on January 11, 1951, the Assistant Custodian of Evacuee Property, Madras City, had declared the property of the vendor to be evacuee property

facts.text: Assistant Custodian rejected confirmation on July 31, 1951 under s. 40(4)(c).

anchor.surface_text: The order refusing to confirm the transaction was passed on July 31, 1951. The appellant challenged the correctness of this conclusion by preferring an appeal

facts.text: Custodian dismissed appeal on February 4, 1953 under s. 40(4)(a).

anchor.surface_text: This order was pronounced on February 4, 1953. The appellant then moved the respondent, the Custodian-General in his revisional jurisdiction.

facts.text: Custodian-General dismissed revision on July 4, 1954 under s. 40(4)(a).

anchor.surface_text: the revisional application preferred before him by the appellant was dismissed by him on July 4, 1954. In his opinion the appellants case fell under s. 40(4)(a)

facts.text: Vendor left for Pakistan in June 1947 on account of civil disturbances.

facts.text: Vendor wrote letter to Mohideen on July 4, 1949 expressing fear of new government rules delaying sale.

facts.text: Ordinance No. XII of 1949 promulgated on June 13, 1949, extended to Madras on August 23, 1949.

facts.text: Ordinance No. XXVII of 1949 came into force on October 18, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: Ordinance No. XII of 1949 was, however, repealed by Ordinance No. XXVII of 1949 which came into force on October 18, 1949.

facts.text: Administration of Evacuee Property Act, XXXI of 1950 came into force on April 17, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: On April 17, 1950, this Ordinance was in turn repealed by Act XXXI of 1950 by s. 58.

anchor.surface_text: Section 25 1  of the Ordinance imposed restrictions on transfers by evacuees. In substance this sub-section provided that transfers made by or on behalf of evacuees of any right or interest in their property after such date as may be specified in that behalf with reference to any Province by the Central Government by notification in the official gazette shall not be effective unless they are confirmed by the Custodian.

concepts.interpretation: Provisions similar to later s.40; restrictions on transfers post-specified date.

anchor.surface_text: Section 38 of this latter Ordinance corresponds to s. 25 of the earlier Ordinance except in one material particular. It provides that no transfer of any right or interest in the property made in any manner whatsoever after the 14th day of August, 1947, by or on behalf of an evacuee as therein specified shall be effective unless it is confirmed by the Custodian.

concepts.interpretation: Similar to s.40(1), fixed date 14 Aug 1947.

issues.text: whether if a transaction had been entered into deliberately and consciously with the object of evading the application of evacuee law which it was apprehended would soon be extended to Madras, does that fact attract the provisions of s. 40(4)(a) of the Act

anchor.surface_text: It is, however, true that no evacuee law had been extended to Madras at the time when the impugned transaction was completed, and that naturally raises the question as to whether if a transaction had been entered into deliberately and consciously with the object of evading the application of evacuee law which it was apprehended would soon be extended to Madras, does that fact attract the provisions of s. 40 4  a  of the Act ?

issues.text: whether the expression good faith in s. 40(4)(a) should be construed in the sense attributed to the said expression by s. 3(22) of the General Clauses Act

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Sastri’s argument is that the expression good faith in s. 40 4  a  should be construed in the sense attributed to the said expression by s. 3, sub-s.  22  of the General Clauses Act, X of 1897. The said provision lays down that a thing shall be deemed to be done in good faith where it is in fact done honestly whether it is done negligently or not.

issues.text: whether the transaction had been entered into in good faith or for valuable consideration under s. 40(4)(a)

anchor.surface_text: The Custodian found in favour of the appellant that the sale transaction in question was supported by valuable consideration even so he proceeded to examine the question as to whether it could be said to have been entered into in good faith.

issues.text: whether good faith is required both in the vendor and the vendee under s. 40(4)(a)

anchor.surface_text: It is clear that if a transaction is affected by absence of good faith either in the vendor or the vendee its confirmation may properly be rejected under s. 40 4  a  in other words, good faith is required both in the vendor and the vendee.

arguments.claim: Transaction ought not to be confirmed under s.40(4)(c) due to feverish hurry in vendor's conduct.

anchor.surface_text: The Assistant Custodian considered the appellants application for confirmation of the transfer in the light of the declaration already made by him that the vendor was an evacuee and that his property was evacuee property. He referred to the relevant features of the transaction and came to the conclusion that he would not be justified in confirming it. It appears that in reaching this conclusion he relied on the provisions of s. 40 4  c  of the Act. In his opinion the feverish hurry disclosed by the conduct of the vendor attracted the provisions of s. 40 4  c .

arguments.claim: Sale transaction supported by valuable consideration.

anchor.surface_text: The Custodian found in favour of the appellant that the sale transaction in question was supported by valuable consideration even so he proceeded to examine the question as to whether it could be said to have been entered into in good faith.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: behalf of an evacuee as therein specified shall be effective unless it is companyfirmed by the Custo

arguments.court_reasoning: All authorities and court agreed on valuable consideration.

arguments.claim: Transaction not entered into in good faith under s.40(4)(a) as vendor intended to dispose of properties quickly to evade anticipated evacuee laws, evidenced by letter to Mohideen.

anchor.surface_text: In dealing with this question the appellate authority considered the fact that the vendor had left for Pakistan in June, 1947, evidently on account of civil disturbances or in fear of such disturbances and that it was obvious that he was permanently settled in Pakistan. According to the appellate authority the vendor was desirous of disposing of his properties in India in order to convert them into cash and take them away to Pakistan. In this connection reliance was placed on a letter written by the vendor to Mohideen on July 4, 1949.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: No. XXVII of 1949 in other words, whatever may be the nature of the circulars and directions issued by the Government of India, the appropriate autho

arguments.court_reasoning: Court upheld interpretation of good faith excluding deliberate evasion of anticipated law.

arguments.claim: Transaction not in good faith under s.40(4)(a) as vendor wanted to evade restrictions of evacuee law soon to be extended to Madras, shown by conduct, haste, and letter.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent considered the matter afresh, and agreed with the finding of the appellate authority that though the transaction was supported by valuable consideration it could not be said to have been entered into in good faith. In support of this conclusion he relied on the conduct of the vendor, the haste with which the transaction was attempted to be completed and the anxiety disclosed by him in his letter to Mohideen. In substance the respondent came to the conclusion that the vendor wanted to evade the restrictions of the evacuee law which he knew would soon be extended to Madras, and that showed that he was not acting in good faith.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: No. XXVII of 1949 in other words, whatever may be the nature of the circulars and directions issued by the Government of India, the appropriate autho

arguments.court_reasoning: Proper construction given to good faith in context of Act's object.

arguments.claim: Since no evacuee law applied to Madras at time of negotiations, vendor free to deal with properties as liked, hence acted in good faith.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Sastri, however, contends that in considering the good faith of the vendor it would be necessary to bear in mind that at the relevant time when negotiations were going on between the parties in respect of the transaction in question evacuee law had not been applied to Madras, and so evacuees like the appellants vendor were absolutely free to deal with their properties as they liked.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: the nature of the circulars and directions issued by the Government of India, the appropriate authorities administering the provisions of the evacuee

arguments.court_reasoning: Anticipation of law and deliberate evasion to defeat it constitutes lack of good faith.

arguments.claim: Government policy was to confirm transfers by Mohammedan evacuees to Indian nationals unless lacking income-tax certificate or other dues.

anchor.surface_text: He also attempted to argue that even where the evacuee law applied, the policy adopted by the Government of India was to confirm transfers made by Mohammedan evacuees in favour of Indian nationals unless a certificate signed by the prescribed income-tax authority certifying that the transferor had paid all taxes due from him to the income-tax department in respect of his property, business or undertaking, or has made satisfactory arrangements for the payment thereof, had not been produced, and unless he had failed to pay any other dues outstanding against him in the Custodians register in respect of his own property and third party claims recognised ex parte by the Custodian.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: iations were going on between the parties in respect of the transaction in question evacuee law had number been applied to Madras, and so evacuees lik

arguments.court_reasoning: Circulars and press notes subject to statutory provisions; authorities must apply relevant law.

arguments.claim: Good faith in s.40(4)(a) construed per s.3(22) General Clauses Act: done honestly whether negligent or not; avoiding anticipated law not dishonest.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Sastri’s argument is that the expression good faith in s. 40 4  a  should be construed in the sense attributed to the said expression by s. 3, sub-s.  22  of the General Clauses Act, X of 1897. The said provision lays down that a thing shall be deemed to be done in good faith where it is in fact done honestly whether it is done negligently or not. The argument is that the vendor could not be said to have acted dishonestly when no evacuee law applied to Madras, and an intention to avoid a law which may be applied to Madras in future cannot be said to introduce an element of dishonesty in his conduct.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: of evacuee law which it was apprehended would soon be extended to Madras, does that fact attract the provisions of s. 40 4  a  of the Act ? As we hav

arguments.court_reasoning: GCA s.3 applies unless repugnant in subject/context; here repugnant given s.40(1) scheme and Act's purpose.

arguments.claim: Absence of good faith by either vendor or vendee justifies rejection under s.40(4)(a); stricter than TP Act s.53(1).

anchor.surface_text: It is clear that if a transaction is affected by absence of good faith either in the vendor or the vendee its confirmation may properly be rejected under s. 40 4  a  in other words, good faith is required both in the vendor and the vendee. In that sense the provisions of s. 40 4  a  are more rigorous and stringent than those of s. 53 1  of the Transfer of Property Act. Under the latter section which deals with fraudulent transfers the rights of a transferee in good faith and for consideration are expressly protected

arguments.claim: Government circulars subject to requirements of relevant statutory provisions like s.38(4) of Ordinance.

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand, the learned Additional Solicitor-General has relied on a copy of a circular issued by the Government of India on March 9, 1950, where it has been stated that the instructions issued by the Government of India are subject to other requirements of s. 38 4  of the Central Ordinance No. XXVII of 1949 in other words, whatever may be the nature of the circulars and directions issued by the Government of India, the appropriate authorities administering the provisions of the evacuee law had to deal with the matters brought before them under the relevant provisions of the said law.

arguments.claim: GCA s.3(22) definition of good faith inapplicable to s.40(4)(a) due to repugnancy in subject or context.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion this argument cannot be accepted. In this connection it is necessary to bear in mind that s. 3 of the General Clauses Act itself provides that the definitions prescribed by the said section are applicable unless there is anything repugnant in the subject or context, and so it would not be unreasonable to hold that the content of the expression good faith would depend substantially on the context of the statute which uses it.

arguments.claim: Meaning of good faith in s.40(4)(a) determined by context of s.40(1), object and policy of Act to preserve evacuee property for inter-government adjustment.

anchor.surface_text: In determining the denotation of the said expression in s. 40 4  a  it would be essential to take into account the scope and effect of the main provisions of s. 40 1 . ... This shows that the main object of the Act was to preserve the property of persons who had migrated to Pakistan till the Government of India could come to some understanding with the Pakistan Government in regard to adjustment of claims of Indian evacuees in respect of the properties left by them in Pakistan.

arguments.claim: Applying broad GCA good faith test would confirm evading transactions, defeating Act's purpose.

anchor.surface_text: Now, if the test prescribed by s. 3 22  of the General Clauses Act as interpreted by Mr. Sastri is held to be relevant a large number of transactions may have to be confirmed even though they are shown to have been deliberately entered into with the object of evading the provisions of s. 40 1 .

arguments.claim: Deliberate intention to evade apprehended evacuee law constitutes lack of good faith under s.40(4)(a), despite law not yet extended.

anchor.surface_text: It is, however, true that no evacuee law had been extended to Madras at the time when the impugned transaction was completed, and that naturally raises the question as to whether if a transaction had been entered into deliberately and consciously with the object of evading the application of evacuee law which it was apprehended would soon be extended to Madras, does that fact attract the provisions of s. 40 4  a  of the Act ?

arguments.claim: Retrospective and drastic provisions of s.40(1) emphasize Act's aim, relevant to construing good faith.

anchor.surface_text: It is significant that though the provisions of s. 40 1  are drastic they have been deliberately made retrospective, and that emphatically brings out the aim and object of the Act and it would be unreasonable to ignore this aim and object of the Act in construing the expression good faith in s. 40 4  a .

holdings.text: If a transaction is affected by absence of good faith either in the vendor or the vendee its confirmation may properly be rejected under s. 40(4)(a); good faith is required both in the vendor and the vendee.

anchor.surface_text: It is clear that if a transaction is affected by absence of good faith either in the vendor or the vendee its companyfirmation may properly be rejected under s. 40 4  a  in other words, good faith is required both in the vendor and the vendee. In that sense the provisions of s. 40 4  a  are more rigorous and stringent than those of s. 53 1  of the Transfer of Property Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.40(4)(a) more stringent than TP Act s.53(1) which protects bona fide purchaser for value; good faith of vendor also required for confirmation.

holdings.text: Circulars and press notes issued by Government do not override or make confirmation automatic; authorities must apply relevant statutory provisions.

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand, the learned Additional Solicitor-General has relied on a copy of a circular issued by the Government of India on March 9, 1950, where it has been stated that the instructions issued by the Government of India are subject to other requirements of s. 38 4  of the Central Ordinance No. XXVII of 1949 in other words,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Instructions subject to statutory requirements like s.38(4); authorities bound by law, not policy circulars alone.

holdings.text: Expression 'good faith' in s.40(4)(a) not construed per s.3(22) General Clauses Act due to repugnancy in subject or context.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion this argument cannot be accepted. In this connection it is necessary to bear in mind that s. 3 of the General Clauses Act itself provides that the definitions prescribed by the said section are applicable unless there is anything repugnant in the subject or context, and so it would not be unreasonable to hold that the content of the expression good faith would depend substantially on the context of the statute which uses it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: GCA s.3 applies unless repugnant; here repugnant given context of s.40(1) scheme requiring stringent good faith to preserve evacuee property.

holdings.text: Deliberate and conscious transaction to evade application of anticipated evacuee law attracts s.40(4)(a) even if law not yet extended to area.

anchor.surface_text: It is, however, true that no evacuee law had been extended to Madras at the time when the impugned transaction was completed, and that naturally raises the question as to whether if a transaction had been entered into deliberately and consciously with the object of evading the application of evacuee law which it was apprehended would soon be extended to Madras, does that fact attract the provisions of s. 40 4  a  of the Act ?

holdings.reasoning_summary: Act's object to preserve evacuee property for inter-governmental adjustment; retrospective provisions; applying broad GCA test would defeat purpose by confirming evasive transactions; vendor's letter shows knowledge and intent.

holdings.text: The sale transaction was not entered into in good faith under s.40(4)(a) and confirmation rightly rejected; respondent's construction of good faith correct.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Upholds lower authorities' findings on vendor's conduct, haste, letter evidencing intent to evade; applies contextual good faith excluding evasion.

anchor.surface_text: It is clear that if a transaction is affected by absence of good faith either in the vendor or the vendee its companyfirmation may properly be rejected under s. 40 4  a  in other words, good faith is required both in the vendor and the vendee. anchor.surface_text: In our opinion this argument cannot be accepted. In this connection it is necessary to bear in mind that s. 3 of the General Clauses Act itself provides that the definitions prescribed by the said section are applicable unless there is anything repugnant in the subject or context, and so it would not be unreasonable to hold that the content of the expression good faith would depend substantially on the context of the statute which uses it.

anchor.surface_text: It is, however, true that no evacuee law had been extended to Madras at the time when the impugned transaction was completed, and that naturally raises the question as to whether if a transaction had been entered into deliberately and consciously with the object of evading the application of evacuee law which it was apprehended would soon be extended to Madras, does that fact attract the provisions of s. 40 4  a  of the Act ?
